params.text:
• Antimony (Sb) occurs naturally in the earth's crust, and is released in high concentrations through mining and processing of antimony-containing ores, and through the burning of fossil fuels.
  • Chronic exposure to antimony in the air can lead to damage to the lungs and airways.
  • Humans are exposed to antimony by eating contaminated food and water, and breathing contaminated particles in the air.

• Arsenic (As) occurs naturally in mineral deposits, but can also come from human activities such as industry and mining.
  • Chronic exposure to arsenic has been linked to cancer as well as cardiovascular (heart and blood vessel) and kidney diseases.
  • The biggest source of arsenic exposure for most people is through the food they eat.

• Barium (Ba) occurs in many different forms (called compounds) in nature. Barium and its compounds are used widely in industrial processes and mining, as well as the production of insect and rat poisons and animal and vegetable oil refining.
  • Chronic barium exposure may be linked to kidney damage.
  • Most people who are exposed to barium are exposed at work. Other exposure comes tby eating or drinking contaminated food or water, or breathing contaminated air.

• Beryllium (Be) occurs naturally in rocks and soil. It has widespread use in the electronics and aerospace industries, and is released into the environment by burning fossil fuels, water and wind breaking down rocks, and volcanic ash.
  • Breathing beryllium over time can cause damage to the lungs, including cancer.
  • Most human exposure to beryllium occurs in the workplace when people work in beryllium manufacturing. Other people are exposed by eating contaminated food or water or breathing contaminated particles.

• While cadmium (Cd) occurs naturally in the earth's crust, industrial processes like the production of dyes and batteries are major sources of cadmium in the environment.
  • Breathing cadmium regularly over time can lead to lung damage and trouble breathing. Other chronic exposure can lead to decreases in bone density or bone disease.
  • Human exposure to cadmium is most common through inhalation of cigarette smoke (another reason not to smoke!), working in cadmium-contaminated workplaces, or eating contaminated food.

Chromium (Cr) is an interesting metal because it is an essential nutrient in humans in one form, called Chromium 3 [written as Cr(III)], but is toxic in another form, called Chromium 6 [written as Cr(VI)]. Let's focus on toxic Cr(VI):

  • Cr(VI) has some natural sources, but the vast majority of this toxic metal in the environment comes from industrial processes such as welding, metal plating, pigment production, and leather tanning.
  • Exposure to Cr(VI) over time, even in low amounts, is linked with cancer.
  • Humans are most commonly exposed to Cr(VI) through inhalation if they work in the industries listed above. Humans are also exposed through eating contaminated food or drinking contaminated water.

• Lead (Pb) occurs naturally in the environment, but human activities including burning fossil fuels, mining, agriculture, and manufacturing release tons of lead into the environment every year.
  • Lead exposure is particularly dangerous for fetuses, infants and children. Lead poisoning can lead to lost attention span, loss of memory, irritability, and nervous system damage.
  • Humans are most commonly exposed to lead through inhalation of dust or air particles contaminated with lead, and eating contaminated food and water.

• Mercury (Hg) is found in many places in the environment, no thanks to its widespread use in the electricity industry and other industrial processes.
  • Chronic exposure to mercury causes damage to the digestive system, nervous system, and kidneys.
  • Humans are exposed to mercury through contaminated food, air, and at work if they are employed in certain industries.

• Thallium (Tl) occurs naturally, but human activities like fossil fuel burning and the metal industry release massive amounts of thallium into the environment.
  • Long-term exposure to thallium causes damage to the nervous system, lungs, heart, liver, and kidneys.
  • Humans are most often exposed to thallium through contaminated foods, especially home-grown fruits and vegetables planted in contaminated soil. Another common exposure source is through inhalation of contaminated air.
